Louisville failed to score a point in teams' first six meetings.

Himmelsbach | Rivalry began as one-sided affair

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 5:44 p.m. EST November 26, 2014

1 CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

At its inception, the football rivalry between the University of Louisville and the University of Kentucky wasn't a rivalry at all. The first game was played on Oct. 28, 1912, and it was a 41-0 UK victory, and it was just a harbinger of things to come. Over 13 seasons, the Wildcats and Cardinals faced each other six times. UK won each game. U of L did not score one point.

Yes, the cumulative score over that stretch was 210-0, and then the series went on hiatus before being rebooted in 1994.

RELATED: Governor's Cup | Kentucky-Louisville primer

The scoring totals from that first stint were jarring and fascinating. I wanted to know more about the stories behind those archaic UK/U of L games. So I headed to The Courier-Journal's third-floor library, an area filled with microfilms of old newspaper pages dating back to the late 1800s.

The first film, which included the Louisville Times account of the 1912 game, was wrapped in a rubber band. The rubber band was so old that when I gave it a slight tug it did not snap, it crumbled. I spooled the film over the machine and leaned in, and history stared back. Here are excerpts from the UK/U of L game stories from the Louisville Times and The Courier-Journal.

Oct. 28, 1912: Kentucky 41, Louisville 0

"The University of Louisville team has about recovered from the effects of the grueling struggle in Lexington, where it lost to State, 41 to 0, and no doubt will present a much stronger appearance next time out. The game last Saturday was a big lesson to the local players, who discovered within the first few minutes wherein they failed to match Coach Sweetland's men."

"State's attack was savage and relentless, and from the sidelines it seemed that Coach Sweetland had the play under his fingertips. He directed the attack, and it was carried out in exactness.No doubt Louisville learned much about the forward pass in that game. Only twice did State's attempts fail." (The Louisville Times)

Nov. 22, 1913: Kentucky 20, Louisville 0

"The State boys on their arrival had a little preliminary street parade, which was followed by the Cardinals' affair at 1 o'clock. All the fellows from U of L wore straw hats."

RELATED: 5 Takeaways | UK's Mark Stoops previews U of L

"Capts. Walker and Black played a good game, breaking up many plays before they got well started. Black made about the only clean tackle for the University of Louisville eleven."

"In the last of the game Park was taken out with a couple of ribs broken, which will keep one of State's best men out of the Tennessee affair on Thanksgiving day." (The Louisville Times)

Nov. 14, 1914: Kentucky 42, Louisville 0

"After fighting gamely against a superior team for three quarters, the University of Louisville eleven weakened in the fourth period and Kentucky University made three touchdowns, the final score being 42 to 0. The Falls City aggregation showed much fighting spirit and time after time made their downs against the locals, but poor tackling and handling of the ball lost them any chance they might have had to score. Louisville was slightly heavier than the team State put on the field, with several second-string men in the lineup, but this advantage was more than lost in the visitors' lack of coaching, their interference falling away or failing to get started. (The Courier-Journal)

Nov. 6, 1915: Kentucky 15, Louisville 0

"The setting was perfect. An autumn sun shone lazily through an Indian summer haze. The ground was dry and the field had not yet lost its emerald blanket. On the western side of the park, the Kentucky state and Louisville enthusiasts filled the bleachers and grandstand. The cardinal and black of Louisville shone bravely against the blue and white of state."

"Both teams relied on old-fashioned football. State was fortunate in fooling the Cardinals with plays which were used in ancient days when they played tackles two-and-a-half yards back from the line of scrimmage. The Cardinals put up a good fight all the way. Even at the finish, they were making the Cadets work overtime to keep the locals away from the goalposts. (The Courier-Journal)

Oct. 14, 1922: Kentucky 63, Louisville 0

"The Cardinals' strength seemed to wane after the initial quarter, and from then on it was a steady march for the goal. The Falls City eleven was up against a team that was too heavy, to experienced and too good for them, but nevertheless the Cardinals never gave up fighting. Many of the visitors were slightly injured and compelled to retire from the contest."

RELATED: Ex-U of L players: UK rivalry intense, heated

"The work of any individual on the Kentucky eleven was not conspicuous enough to warrant him being praised. The Wildcats' playing was uniform." (The Courier-Journal)

Oct. 4, 1924: Kentucky 29, Louisville 0:

"Playing its first game in the new stadium and with one of the largest, if not the largest, opening crowd in Wildcat history looking on, the Blue and White eleven of the University of Kentucky paraded through the University of Louisville line and skirted its ends to a 29-0 victory."

"All of the Cats played much better ball than they have demonstrated in practice, and hopes are considerably brighter in Lexington tonight." (Courier-Journal)

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach
